journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Observer-based H∞ control for Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy systems with uncertainty and disturbance

contrib-group.aff: Department of Electrical Engineering, National Central University, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Wen-June Wang, Department of Electrical Engineering, National Central University, JhongLi 32001, Taiwan. Email: wjwang@ee.ncu.edu.tw

abstract.p: This article is devoted to the design of a fuzzy-observer-based H∞ control for an uncertain Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy system with the existence of external disturbance and unavailable state variables. First, an augmented fuzzy model is built by integrating the system state with the output disturbance to create a new variable. Based on Lyapunov theory and linear matrix inequality tools, we derive sufficient conditions for the existence of the fuzzy-observer-based fuzzy controller guaranteeing a generalized H∞ performance level. A decoupled method is proposed in this study to transform the nonlinear matrix inequality (nonlinear matrix inequality) conditions into some LMI forms. Finally, the procedure of the fuzzy-observer-based H∞ control design is summarized and the effectiveness is demonstrated with a practical example.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fuzzy technique has been widely used in modeling and controlling nonlinear systems. A fuzzy control with IF-THEN rules can be combined with other control methods in order to reach some difficult control objectives because it is capable of modeling complex nonlinear systems.1–5 Among the various kinds of fuzzy models, the Takagi–Sugeno (T–S) fuzzy model is recognized as one of the most popular classes of fuzzy models to dispose off analysis and control problems in complex nonlinear systems.1,4,6–10 Therefore, various kinds of fuzzy control methods based on the T–S fuzzy model have been developed under the so-called parallel distributed compensation (PDC) scheme.11–13

Since in many practical nonlinear control systems, state variables may be unavailable, the design of observers for state estimation plays an important role in automatic control. Therefore, there has been growing interest in fuzzy control for nonlinear systems with T–S fuzzy models using the output-feedback control design.11,14–18 Because the information of the system outputs may not be enough to build T–S fuzzy model of the complex nonlinear system, this applicability is very restricted. A fuzzy observer is also involved as well as the fuzzy controller in the dynamic output-feedback case. In the fuzzy-observer-based output-feedback case, where the premise variables of the T–S fuzzy system are related to the immeasurable state, one needs to design a fuzzy observer estimating the state. Therefore, developing an observer-based output-feedback technique is one of the main goals of this article.

The inclusion of uncertain parameters and output disturbances, which occur due to modeling errors, measurement errors and linearization approximation, is unavoidable in practical control problems. This results in a decline in performance, and even closed-loop systems become unstable. Many methodologies have been proposed to investigate uncertain T–S fuzzy systems with disturbance.19 The article by Tseng and Hwang19 demonstrated a robust adaptive observer for a multiple input multiple output (MIMO) nonlinear system with uncertain nonlinearities and disturbances. However, the existing problem in the Tseng and Hwang study is that the state estimation error is uniformly bounded and does not converge to zero asymptotically; therefore, a fuzzy-observer-based fuzzy controller was developed.20 In the study by Liu,20 the author proposed methods to efficiently attenuate the peak of perturbation due to persistent bounded disturbances. The problems of bounded disturbance were represented21 to deliver a method using the strictly positive real (SPR) theory and Lyapunov stability theory to design the state observer. The existence of the observer-based H∞ control is guaranteed by sufficient linear matrix inequalities (LMIs).14 More importantly, LMI-based new design procedures of fuzzy regulator, fuzzy observers and H∞ controllers are obtained for the T–S fuzzy systems.14 A method of designing an observer-based robust H∞ control for T–S fuzzy systems is proposed,15 subsequently a fuzzy, weighting-dependent Lyapunov function is applied.22 Some of the assumptions in the aforementioned studies impose strict constraints on the feasibility of the designed controller in practical applications.16 These assumptions being the premise variables of both the T–S fuzzy model and the controller only depend on the system outputs. However, the introduction of system outputs is not enough to construct a T–S fuzzy model for a nonlinear system.

In this article, we propose a solution to the observer-based H∞ control problem for uncertain T–S fuzzy systems with output disturbance. First, we generate an augmented system for an uncertain T–S fuzzy model. Then, a fuzzy-observer-based controller is constructed where the premise variables depend on the state variables estimated by a fuzzy observer. In the derivations, the H∞ stabilization and asymptotical estimation conditions are proposed through a five-step design procedure, which are then reconverted into LMIs with the help of an efficient and effective relaxation scheme.23,24 Finally, a computer simulation is conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. The rest of the article is organized as follows. In section “Problem statements,” some preliminaries for a T–S fuzzy model of an uncertain system with output disturbance and problem formulation are given. In section “Fuzzy observer synthesis,” the observer-based H∞ controller is designed and the conditions ensuring global and asymptotic convergence of estimation error are derived as a set of LMI terms. A practical example is given in section “A simulation” to illustrate the design procedure and the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Finally, a conclusion is given in section “Conclusion.”

sec.title: Problem statements
sec.p: A T–S fuzzy dynamic model with uncertainty and disturbance described by IF-THEN rules is considered, which represents the local linear input–output relationship for a nonlinear system. The ith rule of the fuzzy model is shown as the following form
IF θ1(t) is µi1(t) and … and s(t) is µis(t), THEN

where x(t)∈Rn is the state that is unavailable, u(t)∈Rm is the control input, y(t)∈Rp is the measured output, z(t)∈Rq is the controlled output, ω(t) is the disturbance, θj(t)(j=1,2,…,s) are the premise variables and μij(i=1,2,…,r,j=1,2,…,s) are the fuzzy sets that are characterized by membership functions, where r is the rule number and s is the number of the premise variables. The matrices Ai,Bi,Ci,Di,GiandFi have appropriate dimensions. ΔAi is the norm-bounded uncertain parameter matrix, which satisfies the following form
where M and H are known constant matrices of appropriate dimensions and Ξi(t) is an unknown matrix function satisfying
The overall fuzzy model achieved from plant rules in equation (1) is given by
where θ(t)=[θ1(t),…,θs(t)], ψi(θ(t))=Πj=1sμji(θ(t)) and βi(θ(t))=(ψi(θ(t)))/(∑i=1rψi(θ(t))). Hence, βi(θ(t)) is regarded as the normalized weight of each IF-THEN rule and βi(θ(t))≥0,∑i=1rβi(θ(t))=1.

The objective of this article is to design an observer-based controller such that system (4) is asymptotically estimated in the case of ω(t)=0, and system (4) is still estimated with the prescribed H∞ performance level, that is, under the zero-valued initial condition, the nonzero disturbance ω(t)∈L2[0,∞] satisfies

sec.title: Fuzzy observer synthesis
sec.p: In this section, we first consider one particular case with equal output matrices in system (4), that is, Ci=C for all i. Subsequently, this technique will be applied to a general case in which the system contains different output matrices, that is, Ci≠C.

Step 2. Determine the known constant matrices M and H to satisfy equation (2).
Step 3. Solve LMIs (55), (56) and (57) in Theorem 4 to obtain X1,X2,SiandQi, where L¯i=QiX2−TC¯−1 and K¯i=SiX1−T.
Step 4. Construct the fuzzy observer in equation (47).
Step 5. Obtain fuzzy controller rule in equation (45).

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: Consider the dynamics of balancing an inverted pendulum on a cart.8–10
All parameters are the same as those in Example 2 in the study by Gassara et al.,8 and ω(t) is the external disturbance, which is assumed to be ω(t)=cos(2πt)e−0.5t∈L2. We obtain the T–S fuzzy system

The initial is selected as x(t)=[0.250]T,x^(t)=[0.2710]T. Figure 1 shows the result of the closed-loop x(t) and its estimated state x^(t). Furthermore, the control input u(t) is shown in Figure 2, the controlled output z(t) is shown in Figure 3, and the response of error is illustrated in Figure 4. The example shows that the performance of the designed observer-based H∞ fuzzy control is achieved under the existence of uncertain parameters and output disturbance.

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: Consider the dynamics of the single-link robot arm with a revolute elastic joint in a vertical plane in the study by Busawon and Kabore26

sec.p: where d(t) is the same form as the disturbance in the study by Busawon and Kabore,26 that is, d(t) is a measurement noise of 5% of the maximum value of the output with a zero mean and a standard deviation of 1.
Construct the augmented system as below
where
Using the LMI-Toolbox software, there is a set of feasible solutions of the LMIs given in Theorem 4, with γ=0.85

The simulation was realized to demonstrate the improved performance of the proposed observer compared with the proportional high-gain observer (PO) and the proportional integral high-gain observer (PIO) in the study by Busawon and Kabore.26Figure 5 shows the estimate of x3(t) using PO. It is seen that there exists a chattering phenomenon. This is because the disturbance d(t) is multiplied by the proportional high gain. However, reducing the gain to attenuate the effect of the disturbance affects the quality of the convergence. Figure 6 illustrates the estimate of x3(t) using PIO and shows that the convergence is smoother than that using PO. Therefore, PIO has good filtering properties. However, the convergence is not completely reduced to zero. Furthermore, Figure 7 shows the curve of the estimate of x3(t) using the proposed observer-based H∞ control. The estimation performance is much better than that of the preceding two figures. Figure 8 shows the trajectories of state systems, which approach zero. Finally, the proposed observer design solved all of the problems in the study by Busawon and Kabore.26

caption.p: State x3(t) and observer state x^3(t) using proportional high-gain observer.26
State x3(t) and observer state x^3(t) using proportional high-gain PI observer.26
State x3(t) and observer state x^3(t) using the proposed observer-based H∞ control.
Trajectories of the state systems: (a) state x1(t); (b) state x2(t); (c) state x3(t); (d) state x4(t).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, we developed a fuzzy-observer-based H∞ control for a fuzzy system with unknown external disturbance and bounded parameter uncertainty under the conditions that the state variables are unavailable. Whether the fuzzy-observer-based H∞ control has equal output matrices or different output matrices, the estimation of the state and disturbance is achieved. Based on the proposed main theorems, we have derived sufficient conditions for the existence of the fuzzy-observer-based controller to guarantee the asymptotical estimation and stability with a generalized H∞ performance level. A decoupled method is proposed in this study to transform the non-LMI conditions into some LMI forms. The procedure of the fuzzy observer-based control design is also summarized. Simulation results have shown that the observer design is successful.26

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
